div.head: Seminar on the Inclusion of Intelligence Documents in the Foreign Relations Series
div.p: Chairman Warren Kimball opened the session at 1:45 p.m. by stating that the purpose was to get a handle on the selection of intelligence documents that should be included in the Foreign Relations series. He noted that the discussion would proceed on the assumption that HO would continue to have access to intelligence documentation and that the access would expand. Kimball also pointed out that according to all indicators the body of material for HO is sizable, and he wanted to discuss where HO’s emphasis should be so that the amount of material can be used most effectively. Kimball then introduced each of the presenters.

William Slany began the discussion by expressing his desire to emphasize Kimball’s comments. He noted that HO’s access to CIA records has increased and the office looks forward to even greater access to intelligence records. He pointed out that HO now has access not only to CIA, but also to NSA documentation. This year HO acquired approximately 1,000 documents of which up to of 300 were selected for inclusion in Foreign Relations volumes.

Slany explained that HO now has more documentation containing different types of information and is in the process of trying to develop guidelines for its use as well as for its declassification. He noted a central issue facing the Committee was whether or not to recommend that the Department publish volumes with or without CIA documents. Slany said that he had been discussing documents relating to the Soviet Union with Kay Oliver and that a good place to start the discussion was by looking at the case of policy toward the Soviet Union in the Kennedy administration. He then turned the floor over to David Humphrey and Michael Joyce.

Humphrey began by noting that his comments would not be confined to the Soviet Union, but would focus on the more general problem of what kind of intelligence information should be included in Foreign Relations volumes with specific reference to the issues of covert political action and covert paramilitary operations. He noted that the Draft Principles of State-CIA Cooperation refer to “major covert actions undertaken as a matter of U.S. foreign policy,” and asked what that definition actually means.
Humphrey outlined six criteria that could be used to evaluate whether documentation on covert actions could or should be included in Foreign Relations volumes:

item.p: 1) did the covert action bear significantly on U.S. policy;
2) was it considered and approved by the 303 Committee;
3) did top policymakers, such as the President and the Secretary of State, take a direct interest in it;
4) did it involve a substantial sum of money in relation to the country involved;

5) if on a small scale, was it tied to a significant policy initiative (such as support for a group in the process of taking power) or did it eventually blossom into a major covert action and have major consequences; and
6) does publishing the documentation clarify or correct an important issue in the historical record, such as in the case of U.S. non-intervention in Greece in the 1960s?

div.p: Humphrey continued by raising a closely related issue of how much information needs to be included about a covert action or paramilitary operation and by asking whether the action or operation could be documented without revealing sources and methods. He asked whether paramilitary operations could be properly documented without also conveying their scope and consequences, using as an illustration the Bay of Pigs operation.

Humphrey then turned to issues relating to the collection and consumption of intelligence. He noted that there were instances that warranted documentation of clandestine intelligence collection, namely if it affected U.S. relations with another country. He pointed out several examples, such as electronic eavesdropping in the cases of the Maddox, Liberty, and Pueblo, and the effects of intelligence collection on U.S.Pakistani relations in the 1960s. He also raised some related questions, notably, how much of the intelligence operation needed to be revealed in documenting the episode and whether an intelligence relationship with another country merits documentation because it is an integral part of that relationship or only when an operation reaches high-level diplomatic negotiations.

Focusing on intelligence itself, Humphrey asked what makes intelligence worth printing. While pointing out that most intelligence documents printed in Foreign Relations volumes are finished intelligence, raw intelligence could also appear in a volume, for in some instances raw intelligence was provided to the President, such as President Johnson receiving Gulf of Tonkin intercepts. Such raw intelligence is in the files at Presidential libraries and merits inclusion in the Foreign Relations series.

In assessing the role of intelligence in U.S. relations with another country, Humphrey raised two questions: how dependent were policymakers on intelligence as opposed to other sources of information, such as Embassy reports, and to what extent did specific policymakers use intelligence. Humphrey then suggested that several factors be considered when judging the significance of specific intelligence information:

item.p: 1) what did policymakers know about the contents of the intelligence;
2) what did they do with it;
3) did it influence their decisions; and
4) did it analyze circumstances that policymakers were seriously concerned about?

div.p: Humphrey concluded by suggesting that general questions such as those he presented should be considered in evaluating intelligence and covert actions and when considering publishing documents on those issues.

Mike Joyce prefaced his presentation by stating that he would provide a different view of the issue by focusing specifically on the role of intelligence and the USSR. He stated that intelligence was the foundation upon which U.S. policy toward the USSR was built. He described his own intelligence-gathering work going back to 1959 involving collecting and transmitting to Washington bits of intelligence information for analysis. He performed that work in Moscow, Havana, and elsewhere.

Joyce reminded the audience that it was important to keep in mind how little the United States knew about the intentions and capabilities of governments in closed societies, like the USSR and Cuba. He stated that only on the basis of covert as well as overt information could the United States build a picture of the reality in such countries. He emphasized that intelligence was an essential part of the decisionmaking process and that the development of U.S. policy toward the USSR could not accurately be reconstructed by looking solely at diplomatic documents. Instead, he argued, one must examine the bits of intelligence gathered on a daily basis by the CIA, NSA, covert photography (after 1961), and the like.

Joyce went on to explain that each morning higher-level officials wanted to see the bits of intelligence gathered, for the information gave policymakers a daily update on where things stood. He noted that the information came from a mixture of overt information and information acquired by covert means. Most of the intelligence that had an impact on decisionmaking was an analysis of both overt and covert information.

Joyce explained that 1961 was a watershed year in intelligence gathering because of the advent of overhead photography. As a result, the NIEs suddenly became more important because of the inclusion of satellite information. He also noted that the impact of other kinds of intelligence gathering was also significant in formulating policy.

Joyce concluded by stating that accounts of U.S. policy in the 1960s need to include more intelligence and related types of information. In his view, intelligence gathering was at times the most important aspect of U.S. relations with another country, such as Germany, and is part of policymaking decisions.

Martha Mautner began her presentation by explaining her background in the analytical side of intelligence in INR. She estimated that the product of that analysis was an amalgam of information, about 80 percent of which came from open sources and about 2–5 percent from clandestine information. She noted that the finished analysis could be written in unclassified form for public consumption and that individual pieces of covert intelligence were not that important in and of themselves but as a check to confirm information gathered by other means.

In particular cases, such as the Berlin crisis and Ostpolitik, Mautner explained, the United States would not have been able to reach an understanding of the situation without acquiring highly classified information. She noted that Ostpolitik cannot be understood without taking that information into account. She cautioned that there is always some question about covert information, and one must ask why it was provided and if the provider had a particular agenda that must be considered. She noted that important covert information on the USSR and East Germany provided the key to a U.S. understanding of
the Ostpolitik operation and that the information was invaluable to formulating the U.S. position toward and response to Ostpolitik. She emphasized that in that and other instances intelligence is part of the record and the record would not be complete without it. She also cautioned that the value of intelligence to decisionmakers depends on the personalities involved—sometimes a provider had an agenda—and it also depends on the analyst involved.

Mautner noted that in the case of the Berlin crisis the United States had little information from the East German side because it was a closed society and had no contacts with top East German officials or other providers of information in that society. She indicated the importance of intelligence, which came from irregular channels, to the United States in that instance.

Mautner agreed with Joyce, stressing that the information given to U.S. policymakers is an amalgam of overt and covert information and that the totality of information is used in the decisionmaking process. She believed the release of military intelligence was very important, but noted that political information needs to be evaluated as to when, why, and by whom it was given. She concluded by noting that the material must be examined if a history of the period is to be written, and indicated that significant amounts of intelligence information may be available.
Joyce added that one needs to look at intelligence capabilities at a specific point in time, for technological advances produced different types of intelligence.

Brian Latell then took the floor and argued for a threshold to determine what kind of intelligence is important for the Foreign Relations series. He welcomed Humphrey’s six criteria, noting that it was not easy to reach a bottom line or a threshold on the issue, but recommended adding a seventh point to Humphrey’s list: was there a third or fourth country involved in the intelligence operation or covert action and, if so, how much information should be included about that country in the volumes?

Latell then asked what constitutes intelligence sources and analysis. He suggested that to talk only about individual sources may be taking the discussion and the threshold too far, noting that the Agency was very concerned about protecting the individual source. He also asked about requests for raw source information and indicated that it may be useful to discuss that area.

As clarification and background, Latell reported that the Center for the Study of Intelligence has been engaged in an aggressive effort to declassify significant amounts of intelligence information. He noted that over 400 NIEs on the Soviet Union had been declassified and hoped that more of the recent estimates would soon be declassified as well as substantial amounts of other types of intelligence information.

Latell applauded the purpose of this session. He believed one of the purposes was to allow all parties to reach a consensus about the threshold and to give the Center more information about the use of CIA materials in the series. He explained that the position of the Center was to be as open as possible, but he reminded all present that the Center had to work with the Operations Directorate, which is committed to protecting sources and
documents to the greatest extent possible. He ended by noting that the more the issue of threshold is discussed and clarified, the better the situation will become.

Kay Oliver believed that different opinions expressed about the impact of intelligence on policymaking reflected confusion concerning the definitional issue of what constitutes “intelligence.” She noted that CIA officers generally used the term “intelligence” to refer to all-source analysis (i.e., analysis informed by both overt and covert sources). The relative importance of different types of source materials varied from issue to issue. During the period under consideration for this volume (1961–1963), for example, some of the best analysis of Soviet politics done at CIA—the work of FBIS media analysts such as Carl Linden—was based on open source materials. At the same time, for some types of analysis—particularly in the military area—information clandestinely acquired through technical means was of paramount significance.

Oliver noted that in assessing the impact of intelligence on policy, the importance of different categories of intelligence publications varied from one period to the next. During the period in question for this volume, for example, DDI Ray Cline was emphasizing the use of typescripts tailored for particular high-level consumers rather than serial publications such as the Current Intelligence Weekly Review (CIWR). Nevertheless, inclusion of CIWR articles would provide Foreign Relations readers with a flavor of the type of analysis being sent to policymakers.

Joyce reiterated the need to include daily intelligence in the Foreign Relations volumes. He said that policymakers paid more attention to daily intelligence items than to the handful of NIEs that were included in the Soviet Union volume for 1961-1963.

Humphrey suggested that daily intelligence was not appropriate for the volume. What was significant was how the policymakers used intelligence, not simply the fact that the intelligence was produced. Joyce countered that daily intelligence was vital to the creation of a mindset of policymakers.

Latell cautioned against giving too much importance to some daily intelligence or weekly intelligence products, noting from his experience as an analyst that some such serial publications were of low level and represented only the view of a few analysts. Not all daily publications were the products of wide coordination within the intelligence community.
Joyce reiterated his view that daily intelligence was the key.

Kimball then asked about the location of daily intelligence documentation—a question earlier asked by Mel Leffler. Where were the daily intelligence summaries for the President or other principal figures? Edward Keefer suggested that each foreign policy agency created its own daily intelligence file; hundreds of thousands of documents were involved. Luke Smith noted that space limitations in Foreign Relations volumes often meant that only summary portions of NIEs could be printed. He wondered if the CIA should not consider publishing its own series on finished intelligence, which could be used to supplement the Foreign Relations series. Latell thought that was an interesting idea.

Paul Cocks thought that the mix of finished intelligence in the Soviet Union volume for 1961-1963 which he saw, weekly summaries and NIEs, was good, especially when added to the memoranda from McCone.

Emily Rosenberg stated that it seemed as if the discussion had reached an interesting point—CIA arguing for more intelligence coverage and HO holding back. Humphrey stated that HO was not holding back on covering covert operations, far from it, but the historians felt that finished intelligence was massive—even that which made it into the White House files—and should not overwhelm the series.
Joyce stated that he thought that the 1961-1963 Soviet Union volume needed more intelligence assessments on the Soviet economy.

Keefer suggested that the access to both finished and covert operations documentation was increasing, and although each new Presidential administration created more important records, the size of the series was either static or shrinking. Kimball suggested that the growth in documentation necessitates a need for greater and more careful assessment of intelligence materials to be included.

Latell offered the idea that perhaps the solution to Joyce’s concern was to add a sample of different kinds of intelligence. Rosenberg asked if one of the problems with using documents on covert operations was the issue of foreign liaison with allies. Keefer suggested that this was the major problem.
The meeting adjourned for a break and resumed at 3:20 p.m.

Continuing the discussion of intelligence, Kimball proposed that the group focus on such questions as what to look for and what’s there. Van Camp asked for information on the CIA’s archives. Oliver responded that CIA records were organized on the basis of functional components. The types of documentation created corresponded to the type of work the component did, analytical work being far different from operational activities.

After Joyce commented on the need to remember that there were a variety of members in the “intelligence community,” he and Humphrey exchanged views on what criteria should be employed in the selection of intelligence records for Foreign Relations volumes. Joyce viewed intelligence as the humus out of which policymaking decisions were made. Thus, the volumes should be rich in use of these materials. Humphrey tended to view intelligence records as important in relation to the level at which they were employed. White House and high-level State Department files were a guide to what was important. Keefer added that the records were too voluminous for any but the most limited inclusion. Schwar suggested a statement in the preface to indicate the limits on using these records.

The CIA representatives then discussed the value of the various intelligence products they were involved with. The question of the importance of NIEs and NIDs within the policymaking process was discussed. HO historians tended to argue that each volume needed to be treated on a case-by-case basis but that intelligence definitely had a role in the volumes.

Rosenberg indicated that she found the discussion disturbing, since it suggested that the Foreign Relations volumes did not allow adequate space to document properly the decisionmaking process and the role of intelligence in it. Michael Hogan asked whether the compilers felt that they were able to incorporate intelligence adequately. Humphrey responded that he felt comfortable with the amount of intelligence incorporated in the Vietnam volumes for 1965 and 1966, but George Herring noted that Vietnam was unusual in the number of volumes devoted to it.

Kimball asked whether we can get our arms around the volume of intelligence material. How can the Committee help HO historians deal with the amount of material? Commenting on the problem of limited space that Smith had emphasized, Oliver stated that NIEs were worthwhile and that maybe Joyce’s idea of sampling intelligence material should be explored. Don Steury noted problems with recordkeeping in the Directorate of Intelligence—it was not easy to find what you wanted.

Bruce Duncombe and Jane Picker raised the issue of the Aldrich Ames case and its implications for using intelligence. What would historians like to see? Kimball noted that we are writing the history of foreign policy and not intelligence.

Turning to the question of covert action, Rosenberg asked about the significance of the seventh criterion—concerning liaison with third countries—that Latell had added to Humphrey’s criteria. Would it be an occasional stumbling point or a regular one? Oliver thought it would have a rather broad impact. Keefer saw it as the principal problem. Humphrey noted that his six criteria were criteria for including covert actions in Foreign Relations volumes, whereas Latell’s was a criterion for excluding them. Jerry Monroe commented that relations with a country that was an object of covert action was also commonly a complicating factor.

Kimball asked how can we be confident that we have at least been shown all the relevant material on covert actions. Oliver commented that there was reason for more confidence than in the past. Smith noted that we now have access to records of the 303 Committee.
The Committee adjourned at 4:30 p.m.

div.head: Open Session, December 12
div.p: Prior to the beginning of the meeting, members of the Advisory Committee were photographed by the State Department photographer for inclusion in a future issue of State magazine.

Chairman Kimball convened the open session at 9:17 a.m. and issued the customary warning about discussion of classified material. He then asked for approval of the minutes of the July 1995 meeting. One correction was called for by Kimball and approved. The minutes as amended will stand.

Kimball then turned to the approval of agenda. Slany said that there were no changes other than that a different attorney would be attending on behalf of the Legal Adviser’s Office. Kimball then asked Slany as Executive Secretary to give a report.

div.head: Report of the Executive Secretary
div.p: Slany advised the Committee members that since they already had a general written report on the status of the Foreign Relations series in their packets, he would bring them up to date on other matters.

div.head: Series Goals and Staff Vacancies
div.p: Slany said that the staff has achieved much in implementing the 1991 statute but continues to have great difficulty in fitting more documentation into smaller volumes and had not been successful in meeting the ambitious goals for completion. He said that the project was slipping behind in some areas and not all Kennedy volumes will have been published by 1996. The problem was exacerbated by two professional staff vacancies: the Deputy Historian/General Editor and a historian in the European Division. He explained that even with a full staff, it was hard to make the series broader and more inclusive and still keep up the pace. Slany welcomed the advice of the Committee on what to do about the problem.

div.head: Declassification
div.p: Slany noted that the matter would be discussed in the closed session.

div.head: Introduction of New Staff
div.p: Slany introduced Kent Sieg who has joined the Asia and Americas Division. He noted that Sieg is compiling materials for the Vietnam volumes, an area in which he is very experienced.

div.head: New Access to Intelligence Documents
div.p: The staff takes great pride in the wider inclusion of intelligence materials, including those of the NSC, CIA, and other special group files. Slany said that the staff would soon gain access to documents from the President’s Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board. David Patterson explained that the materials were an additional record and would supplement the documentation in the Presidential libraries.

As an example of the benefits derived from these newly available archives, Slany cited the Kennedy/Khrushchev correspondence collection in which the staff turned to the records of the Russian Foreign Ministry to fill in the gaps. While the Russians could not provide everything, the volumes had moved forward toward publication.

div.head: The Continuing Case of Guatemala
div.p: Slany said that the staff had been working with the CIA historians on the Guatemala problem. The CIA had intended to hold a conference and release a facsimile publication dealing with the 1954 events but now will not be able to do so within the next year. It seems desirable, Slany said, for HO to pursue this publication as part of the Foreign Relations series since senior Foreign Service advisers Bill Marsh and Jerry Monroe have already collected approximately 900 documents. Selections from this collection would be compiled in a larger Eisenhower volume that also will include materials on Iran, Indonesia, and any other covert actions that may be relevant. “While we would like to cooperate with the CIA,” Slany said, “if they can’t do it, it seems unreasonable to delay.”

Slany went on to explain that with the staff already fully committed, HO would propose to use senior Foreign Service advisers to assist in the compilation of compile the volume. Kimball said that perhaps the Committee should seek reaction to the proposal to
move this volume from the back burner to a priority. Hogan asked why the CIA could not hold a conference. Slany replied that the CIA historians had not yet gained the full endorsement of their own agency but that the leadership of the Department of State was behind it.

Hogan then asked if there was a better prospect of moving ahead without the CIA historians. Slany agreed. Kimball added that the CIA History Staff was not opposed to State’s initiative on this matter, and Slany said that State will still try to get CIA’s cooperation.

Kimball said that the Committee should go on record in support of the entire project, which will include Iran, Indonesia, Guatemala, and “any other significant bits of information.” The volume will be about 800 to 1,000 pages. Rosenberg asked if extra money hadn’t been found to do the compiling a year ago, and referred to a presentation by Steve Kane (PA/PC), who was the compiler of the 1952-1954 Guatemala volume. Slany explained that Kane’s assignment involved no funding, but was a limited detail.

Kimball then asked if it was appropriate for the Committee to ask for an expansion of resources. Rosenberg felt that it was most appropriate for Slany himself to decide who will do the compiling, and Picker commented that the Committee would not want its actions to preclude Slany from going forward. Kimball then called for a vote, which was unanimous in favor of proceeding with the volume.

div.head: Management of the Historical Advisory Committee
div.p: Because the work of the Committee has expanded, the amount of time and money to support the work of the Committee has also expanded. Slany said that HO has added a staff member, Gloria Walker, to provide needed staff support. In addition, in order to track reimbursement for travel and expenses, Rita Baker will supplement the existing effort to bring the claims up-to-date.

Slany also said that the Internet may be a useful vehicle for dissemination of information. Next year, HO will try to put out biweekly reports on the Internet, which will be available to everyone. He believes that there is enough going on in the “dark periods” between meetings to distribute information more broadly and more regularly.

The Advisory Committee’s charter is open for revision every 2 years, Slany said, and it will be circulated to those who do not currently have a copy with a request for revision suggestions. Kimball said that everyone should have a red-covered copy and advised those who did not to get one from HO. Picker and Vince Davis needed copies.

Kimball also asked that revision suggestions be sent to him before the next scheduled meeting in February. He stressed that the charter was an important document within the State Department because it gave the Committee authority.

div.head: Documents on Disarmament
div.p:
The last volume published in this series covered 1986, and ACDA is responding to the recommendation of the Inspector General’s report to abolish the position of ACDA historian, which has been occupied only on a sporadic basis since the late 1980s. The IG report also recommended that the documents collected since the last published volume be turned over to HO. Slany said that steps will be taken in
coordination with ACDA to ensure the distribution of the important arms control agreements and documents of the late 1980s and early 1990s, but no decision has been made on how exactly to proceed given the lack of staff. He said that at a minimum the documents would be made available in an electronic format and that a decision would be made in the next 6 weeks or so.

div.head: Follow-up From July 1995 Meeting
div.p: Kimball noted that at the last session Slany had expressed concern about personnel issues and asked for an update. Slany said that a short-list of candidates for the Deputy Historian/General Editor now existed and, once the leadership of the PA Bureau had examined the list, a decision would be forthcoming perhaps as early as December.

Slany explained that a candidate had been selected for the 4-year position in Humphrey’s division and had just finished the DS clearance process. However, he added, severe budgetary constraints meant that the Bureau must seek to reconfirm this exemption from the hiring freeze. Slany explained that while this would not be easy, he was “fairly sanguine” about the possibility of success.
No additional questions or concerns were raised by the Committee.

div.head: Preparation for the Nixon and Ford Volumes
Access to the Nixon Project
div.p: Slany introduced Nancy Smith of the Office of Presidential Libraries of the National Archives and David Wigdor, Chief of the Modern Manuscript Division of the Library of Congress. As an introduction to their comments, Slany said that HO had a research plan that was being advanced and that five or six historians would begin work next year in the Nixon collections.

Smith then reported that good progress had been made on gaining access to the Nixon project materials. She had arranged two meetings between the Department of State and the Nixon lawyers to share information on both the needs of the historians as well as the type of access agreements the lawyers will require. Smith assured the Committee that based on her conversations with Stan Mortenson, the main Nixon lawyer, Foreign Relations historians would have access to textual Presidential historical materials.

Smith said that HO researchers may begin work in the National Security Files at any time and that action is currently with the Department of State to draft an access agreement on taking copies back to State that will maintain of the copies status as Nixon historical materials. She explained that discussion on access for Foreign Relations historians to the approximately 3,700 hours of audiotapes had been reserved for the future.

Kimball asked if “sheer access” was the issue over the tapes, to which Smith responded in the affirmative. She believed that Mortenson wanted to see how research in the paper collections proceeded before making decisions about tapes—there is no access at the moment. Smith said her impression was that the Nixon lawyers believe that the Foreign Relations series is important.

Kimball then asked the HO staff if use of the tapes usually came after searches of the paper collections were complete. Patterson said yes and Humphrey agreed, explaining that it had been done that way because “we’ve had to.” He added that this was not a particularly desirable way of proceeding.

Smith explained that there were no transcripts of the tapes. She urged the historians to get into the paper collections since the volume was so much greater than those of Presidents Kennedy or Johnson.

Hogan asked if deterioration of the tapes should be a concern in the access debate. Smith said that although the National Archives had made a new archival preservation copy of the Nixon tapes beginning in 1992, the original tapes eventually would deteriorate because magnetic tape was not a permanent medium.

Michael Schaller asked if access was limited to the National Security Files. Smith said that discussions had been geared to this file as being the most obviously useful to the historians, but that access had been granted to all the textual files. She explained that NARA must review all materials proposed for inclusion in Foreign Relations according to the seven factors in the Presidential Recordings and Materials Preservation Act (PRMPA). Access itself was not a problem but the issues of providing copies to Foreign Relations historians and making copies available to the public might be a problem; someone—Henry Kissinger for example—may object to opening the items. Again, she emphasized that Mortenson wants a memorandum of understanding. David Herschler added that the right to take copies back to the office must be part of the agreed arrangement.

Herring asked if the declassification procedure will be complicated. The process will not be like dealing with the other Presidential collections, Smith explained, because the Nixon materials are covered by a unique statutory authority (the PRMPA) and additionally complicated by the ongoing mediation process and court injunctions. She said that everything must be declassified and reviewed in accordance with the authorities governing the Nixon material and that NARA will then publish a Federal Register notice that will give people 30 days to object. Kimball quizzed her on what the grounds for objection could be and whether or not such grounds were detailed in the law.

Smith said that the grounds could be invasion of individual privacy or that the item is personal and returnable. If an objection were lodged, the dispute would go to the Presidential Materials Review Board, chaired by the Archivist, which would look at the issue and reach a decision. If the decision was to open the document, the individual would have 30 days to file an objection in court. Herring asked if this meant literally anyone who was mentioned.

Smith explained that the Archives had a list of about 70 individuals who were always alerted when any materials were opened, in addition to the Federal Register notice, and explained that this was the source of her concern about declassification. Again, she urged the historians to get into the documents as soon as possible.

Given your experience, Kimball asked Smith, will the kinds of documents we pull cause problems? Yes, Smith replied, although she declined to mention specific names. NARA already has a collection of 200 hours of Watergate-related tape that it will propose
for release when the litigation is resolved. She again explained that it was her impression that Mortenson and the other Nixon people support the Foreign Relations series and were willing to be cooperative. Anne Van Camp asked if Smith thought that the documents “would be released in your lifetime?”

Smith responded that she would love to have all the tapes open since they have been closed for 22 years. She added that it was hard to be optimistic or pessimistic because whenever a breakthrough seemed imminent, something always came up.

Schwar asked if the Nixon family had the right, in addition to the 70 named individuals, to review the documents. Absolutely, Smith responded. Would the declassification review take place before the NARA review, Humphrey asked, and would NARA oversee the review by other government agencies with an interest in declassification? Smith explained that the declassification review would take place first, and then when it was clear what HO wanted, NARA would then see if the Nixon estate objected. Humphrey restated his question for clarification: after HO has gotten a volume reviewed and declassified then NARA will do its review? Smith said that was correct, but mechanisms will be established to speed the process along.

div.head: Access to the Kissinger Papers
div.p: Kimball then turned to the Kissinger collection at the Library of Congress. Wigdor said that the Committee’s request for a report came at an opportune time since the Library had been organizing the Kissinger papers for the past 2 years so that the collection will be an easy one to use. The Library has written to Kissinger about the HO access question but there had not yet been time for a response. Wigdor said that over the years Kissinger’s papers have been used by various State Department offices so that he was “guardedly optimistic” about access. He believes that there will be no administrative problems except regarding copying classified documents. The biggest problem will be finding the staff to work with HO in handling such large requests. Security is the biggest problem, and the documents will have to be carried by a State Department courier.

Kimball asked if there were donor restrictions, and Wigdor said not of the magnitude of the Nixon papers. Van Camp asked if Kissinger could refuse access; Wigdor said yes. Kimball interjected that the question of whether the papers were public or private was challenged in court and that the public lost—the papers are considered to be private.

Humphrey asked if a description of the collection existed. HO has an old description, but a new one is being drafted, Wigdor said. He explained that the collection covered the same papers Kissinger used in drafting his memoirs. The Library is hopeful that he will add more papers in the future, but the collection at the moment covers only 1969-1976. Wigdor explained that access was restricted to the documents for either 25 years from the date of the document or until after Kissinger’s death, whichever was later. He assumed, at this point, that lifetime closure was most likely.

Rosenberg then asked if the documents could now be selected and declassified. Not in their present status, Wigdor said. Herring asked if Kissinger could add other conditions in granting access. Wigdor said yes.

Davis asked if other materials, such as the Kissinger-Rockefeller correspondence, are in the collection. No, Wigdor explained; if he is the donor, Kissinger still owns the correspondence, which means that he has the rights over it, although not, perhaps, copyright.

Kimball asked what the law says regarding public access to private collections of government officials that include classified materials. Can these materials be declassified? Picker cited the example of an author who was not allowed to have a copy of her own book pending declassification. In the case of the Kissinger papers, Wigdor said that declassification still requires the permission of all agencies with equity. Dan Lawler said that for the last several years classified information has been considered, by definition, the property of the government.

Wigdor said that it worked the other way as well: If a document was stamped classified in one collection but not in another, then it was released, e.g. the Oppenheimer papers at Princeton. The journals of AEC Chairman Glenn Seaborg were another example of an agency (Energy) preventing the release of documents, Patterson interjected. The Department of Energy held up publication of his private journals while they excised classified material. Smith said that NARA held the Mondale papers for the University of Minnesota because the University could not house classified documents. But the Humphrey papers are at the Minnesota Historical Society, Van Camp said. How is declassification handled in such cases, Patterson asked. Kimball asked if the guidelines in the new Executive Order were interpreted to mean that these non-governmental holders of classified materials must do their own systematic review. Smith said that FOIA cannot be done since they cannot be considered federal records if held in a university library.

div.head: Status of Foreign Building Operations Records
div.p: Slany then introduced Jane Loeffler, who has recently completed her doctoral dissertation on the history of buildings at overseas Embassies. She voiced concern about the “housekeeping” practices of the Department’s Office of Foreign Building Operations. Because the office no longer has an archivist, she believes that an important collection of documents and photographs is not being preserved or adequately controlled. Loeffler said that many records could no longer be found and that staff members could sign out materials with no adequate controls. Kimball said that she should consult with the NARA representatives during the break. Smith said that Loeffler should speak with her colleague, Michael Kurtz, who was in attendance, and Kimball concurred.
The session adjourned at about 10:30 am.

div.head: Information Management Issues
div.p: Kimball called the meeting to order at 10:45. He said that they needed to continue the previous discussion and that Nancy Smith and Michael Kurtz would speak to these issues. He noted, however, that some questions concerning information management had been raised during their Monday meeting with Ken Rossman. Since Kurtz could not come back after lunch, he suggested that they deal with these first.

Van Camp said that she wanted to bring up a very practical idea that had arisen during their discussion with Rossman. In its declassification review, the Department of State separated the files that may be opened from those that will remain classified. Rossman had suggested that the Department might put these in archival boxes and label them before shipping them to NARA. Committee members thought this sounded like a good idea, and Kurtz agreed that it was one that NARA would support.

Van Camp noted that a larger issue that had arisen during their discussion was how to transfer the Department’s electronic records to NARA. Rossman had said that by 1998, State would be transferring its files (beginning with 1973) in electronic form. The Department planned to send the data tapes to NARA without the software used here. The Advisory Committee’s concern was that the software was also part of the record and that NARA should have this as well. She wanted NARA’s reaction to this concern. A third issue was what was going to happen to such records in the future. Should the Department keep control of these records with NARA providing access?

Kurtz responded that these were very complicated issues. NARA had been exploring ways to handle electronic records. One possibility was the non-custodial method used in Australia and Canada, under which government agencies kept control of the records and the archives set standards and arranged access. He noted that there were problems with the OASIS system, which they had had a meeting to explore. They were planning to set up a joint State-NARA group to work out methods of transferring electronic records. This was going to require lots of interagency dialogue and would be a long process. There was not going to be an abrupt change.
Kimball asked if the Advisory Committee could have a report on this at their next meeting. Kurtz suggested that it be at the following meeting.

div.head: Implementation of Executive Order 12958 on National Security Information
div.p: Kimball proposed that the discussion return to the issue of implementation of the Executive Order, which Smith and Kurtz could address. Ethel Theis, Associate Director of ISOO, would either answer questions or make a statement. Theis said she would do whatever the Committee wanted.
John Kropf from L said that he was there to answer one question, whether “should” was mandatory or discretionary, and that the short answer was that it was discretionary.

Kurtz reported that NARA had been working on implementation of the Executive Order since it was signed in April. In June, there had been an interagency meeting to assess classified files, of which there are an estimated 460 million pages. He noted that there were three categories of classified files:

item.p: 1) files that were so replete with sensitive material that they were exempt;
2) files that had to be looked at; and
3) files that were not so sensitive, requiring little or no review.

div.p:
NARA was now doing for the agencies a more detailed review of classified files, finding aids, equities, etc. NARA had also briefed various agencies on implementation of
the Executive Order, including DOD, but most were leaning toward page-by-page review. Some agencies had already submitted their plans for implementation. Kurtz noted that NARA was very concerned about the need for on-site review.

Smith said that the Office of Presidential Libraries had sent a plan to the National Security Adviser for declassification of the 7 million pages of classified material at the Presidential libraries, including many high-level policy papers. She gave some examples of the number of pages of classified documents: The Hoover Library has 22,750 pages, and the Roosevelt Library has 2,000-3,000 pages. The big collections were at the Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, and Ford Libraries.

Smith stated that NARA would like to give high priority to material on Vietnam and Southeast Asia (at the Kennedy, Johnson, and Ford Libraries)—around 250,000 pages—because of high interest by researchers in this material. Much of this sort of material has been declassified in other places, and most of it could be declassified. NARA is proposing reviewing files by subject but is willing to consider any approach that would deal with the Presidential papers in a systematic way. NARA wants to propose systematic declassification at the Truman and Eisenhower Libraries but is waiting until next year.

Smith noted that NARA is concerned that some agencies want to address low-level material first and delay dealing with the high-level material. NARA wants Presidential papers included in the first year of declassification because of researcher interest. Some proportion of high-level material should be released in the first year.

Smith stated that some agencies are proposing the use of optical disc scanning and expressed concern that much delay might be involved in working out the technical aspects and coordinating different approaches by the different agencies. NARA planned to discuss this with the agencies. She noted that the Executive Order requires declassification of a proportion of the classified material each year.

Kurtz emphasized the need to discuss the problems with the technological approach. NARA needed to get the agencies together. NARA was open to suggestions. He noted that under the Executive Order, everything not reviewed was to be declassified at the end of 5 years, which leaves NARA with real problems. He asked Leffler if he agreed that the DOD meeting on implementation of the Executive Order had seemed to be very conservative. Leffler replied that he would not disagree with that assessment.

Kimball asked Theis if ISOO had any comments. Theis noted that they were dealing with a culture in which many agencies think that everything they create has to be classified. The Executive Order would help to change this culture. Agencies were beginning to come around, but they had to keep working at changing their outlook.

Kimball asked Theis about oversight. She replied that the Executive Order created an appeals panel, the Information Security Policy Advisory Council, with representatives from the major classifying agencies, which would have to review material declared exempt from declassification and report to the President. Maybe this would help Smith address some of her problems and help in reaching a compromise. She noted that the Council had not yet been set up, and that its members had to be appointed by the President. Kimball
said that a copy of anything the Advisory Committee decided would be sent to Steve Garfinkel.

Kimball declared the session open for discussion. Van Camp asked whether an interagency group could get together. Kurtz stated that he and Smith had been meeting with an interagency declassification subcommittee under ISOO, chaired by Steve Garfinkel. Smith noted that she was not saying that the agencies were not cooperating, but rather that each agency was dealing with its own problems. Kimball asked if it would be useful for the Advisory Committee to encourage this sort of interagency dialogue. Smith replied that it would, and that if the Advisory Committee wanted high-level declassification in the first year, it should say so.

Tony Dalsimer stated that HDR was working on Top Secret files through 1976; it had started with the most difficult files, rather than the less difficult files. Kurtz asked whether the Department had NSC and DOD declassification authority. Dalsimer replied that it had DOD authority, but no NSC authority.

Kimball said that the Advisory Committee would express its interest in declassification of high-level material and point out that the Department of State was already doing this. Leffler suggested that the letter be sent also to DOD, where there seemed to be no interest in reviewing high-level files. Theis suggested that the Committee might also want to send a letter to National Security Adviser Anthony Lake asking that the Advisory Council be established as soon as possible because it was supposed to specify categories for systematic review. Kimball said that this was a good idea. Page Miller agreed that the person to write to was Anthony Lake. The Committee agreed, and Kimball said that this would be coordinated with Page Miller.

Rosenberg suggested that after the establishment of the ISOO Advisory Council, the Committee should send them a letter outlining some of its experiences that might be relevant to their structure and procedures.

Kimball asked if there were any other issues NARA wanted to raise, to which Kurtz replied no. Rosenberg asked Kurtz if he was concerned with how many files would be exempt from declassification. Kimball asked how many such files there were. Kurtz said that NARA did not have that information. Agencies were working on it and DOD had an extension. Theis said that some agencies had submitted declassification plans as required under the Executive Order. Steve Garfinkel thought that some of the exemptions agencies had requested were too broad, and ISOO was negotiating with those agencies.

Kimball asked what the Department of State was doing. Frank Machak said that the Department would request exemption of three categories of files—central files, lot (office) files, and post files—in order to do a page-by-page review. Leffler asked whether the Department planned to exempt everything and then review it. Machak pointed out that the Department’s declassification record was 97 percent. Kimball said the Committee was asking about process, not criticizing the Department’s record.

Leffler asked again whether everything would be exempt. Machak replied no. Kimball asked if this meant automatic declassification for some files. Machak said no; he was talking about risk assessment. Kimball commented that if the Department of State,
which had the best declassification record, did not have any files that would be automatically declassified, it did not look good for implementation of the Executive Order. Machak stated that when reviewers were reviewing the files, some files required intensive review and some required very little, but it was not possible to identify those files in advance.

Kimball asked what would happen after 5 years. Theis said that 180 days before the end of the 5-year period, an agency would have to make a request for an extension and state why certain files should still be exempt. Kimball asked how often the Advisory Council would meet. Theis said twice a year. Kimball asked if that constituted “heavy involvement” and she responded that it was supposed to meet at least twice a year. Kimball asked if the Advisory Council members would have clearances; Theis said yes. He asked which organizations had been asked to submit nominations for the Council. Theis read the names of some of the organizations, including the American Historical Association, the Society of American Archivists, and the Society for International Law. Kimball commented that the Council needed to get underway fast.

Kimball noted that the Advisory Committee had not yet finished its discussion of the Executive Order and its implementation; it needed to allow time after lunch to discuss this further. The meeting adjourned at noon for lunch.

div.head: Closed Session, December 12
div.p: When the meeting reconvened at 1:30 p.m., Kimball asked Langbart about Naval records stored at the Naval facility at Crane, Indiana, and mentioned specifically the Maddox, Pueblo and Liberty incidents. Langbart said that these were the records of the Naval Security Group Command and included inactive and active station files. He added that it did include a special set of files for the Liberty and investigation of the Pueblo incident particularly, and that the files were rather voluminous. Herring asked where Crane is located, and Herschler responded that it was half an hour southwest from Bloomington, Indiana.

div.head: More on Implementation of Executive Order 12958
div.p: Kimball asked Kropf if he had any comments concerning the implementation of E.O.12958.

Kropf raised one question previously addressed to him in writing: is it mandatory or discretionary to refer documents containing foreign government information (FGI) to a foreign government? Kropf said the ISOO guidelines indicate that State “should” refer such documents to the foreign government, but that, in his opinion, “should” implies an element of discretion. If so, this would not represent a change in the status quo. He thought Theis would agree with this interpretation; Theis nodded in agreement.

Picker asked for a specific reference to the Executive Order that would support this interpretation, i.e., that “should” implies discretion. Kropf cited references to FGI in the definition (ID) and automatic declassification (3.4) sections of the E.O. After some discussion, Kimball explained that the Committee wanted to know specifically where “should” appeared in relation to the handling of FGI; Kropf replied that the language came
from the ISOO Implementing Directive. Kimball expressed concern that “should” could also be interpreted to require mandatory referral of FGI.

Dalsimer said that there was no need to change present practice: the State Department would continue to implement its policy minimizing the referral of documents to foreign governments. He said the Department had recently discussed the issue with the British, Australian, and Canadian Governments. The Department is also drafting guidelines to delegate limited declassification authority, similar to those adopted by DOD.

Kimball raised the issue of FGI for foreign governments that no longer exist. Machak had already conceded that the Soviet Union no longer exists, Kimball argued, so the Soviet Union should not be considered under the E.O. provision to protect FGI. Kimball turned to Machak for clarification. Machak said the new E.O. allowed nine exemptions to declassification; he did not recall an exemption for FGI. In other words, under the new E.O., FGI is not sufficient grounds to exempt a document from declassification, whether or not the originating government exists.

Kimball feared a “disconnect” in the current lines of communication. The Committee understood that documents had been routinely withheld on the basis of FGI. Would a document originated in 1965 by the Soviet Government be considered classified today? Machak said only limited circumstances would force the Department to refer documents to a foreign government. The Department did not interpret the new E.O. to require the referral of all FGI.

Kimball said he was not talking about the Executive Order, he was talking about practice. He reiterated the question: how does the Department handle FGI when the foreign government doesn’t exist? Kimball cited South Vietnam as an example, i.e, the Department does not refer documents originated by the former Republic of Vietnam to the current Communist government in Hanoi. Kimball thought the same practice would now apply to the Soviet Union. In response to Kimball’s question, Machak said he did not see the Department adopting the position that documents originated by the former Soviet and South Vietnamese Governments be handled in the same way.

Picker remarked that the Department could not send documents if no one is there to receive them. Kimball agreed. Picker also reminded the Committee that the new E.O. does not include FGI as a declassification exemption category. Kimball said he knew that.

Kimball mentioned a case at the Johnson Library in which a memorandum of a conversation with Andrei Gromyko had been withheld on the basis of FGI. Dalsimer suggested that Kimball address the question to Nancy Smith, since the Department is handling FGI in accordance with the Committee’s wishes.

Smith said that NARA had not received any guidance under the new E.O. that would change the current practice for handling FGI: documents containing FGI are sent to State. In other words, it’s still State’s call.
Kimball retorted that the Committee does not want it to be State’s call.

Theis said the question is: if a foreign government no longer exists, who has authority? She said that the question of how to handle the FGI of the former Soviet
government had come up in a recent meeting of the declassification working group. The working group determined that the new Federation should assume responsibility. Kimball asked what Federation she meant. Theis repeated the point: the successor government would take over authority. Picker explained that the Russian Federation acknowledged itself as the “successor government” to some extent; Picker asked, however, if this authority extended to FGI. Kimball replied that the responsibility for determining FGI rests with the U.S. Government. Kimball said that he wanted to avoid using FGI as a reason to withdraw documents and that State had agreed to justify withdrawal on other grounds.

Dalsimer admitted that Kimball was right: a State Department document would not remain classified solely on the basis of FGI. Dalsimer also said that NARA had State Department guidelines that cover FGI. Nancy Smith replied that NARA has very little declassification authority, and is otherwise not in a position to determine FGI.
Machak said the Department would make certain that the guidelines are clear, but that each agency would be responsible for applying the guidelines in a sensible way.
Kimball expressed some concern about a misunderstanding between NARA and the Department regarding State’s willingness to delegate its declassification authority to the Presidential libraries.

Patterson said his experience had been that HDR would not refer documents to the Soviet Union, reasoning that it was unnecessary to send documents to our enemies. Kimball said that this point was understood.

Machak insisted that South Vietnam is not a good example. The Department would judge on a case-by-case basis rather than rely upon sweeping generalizations. Turning to Machak, Kimball shot back: “we understand that the words ‘page-by-page’ are printed on the backs of your eyes.”
Kimball asked if Theis had any comments on the implementation of the E.O. and ISOO’s role in the process.

Theis noted that she is always ready to talk about these issues, and commented that it would be best for the Committee to ask her questions. She reminded the Committee of Kimball’s inquiry regarding oversight; she wondered if anyone required clarification.

Kimball said he had written a letter to Steve Garfinkel; Theis said she had seen it. Kimball asked if she would comment on it, especially the questions he posed in the letter. Specifically, who will ensure agency compliance with the requirement for agency guidelines to NARA. Theis said that ISOO is responsible for making sure that the guidelines are timely and up-to-date. ISOO is now a part of NARA, and NARA participates in the declassification working group. This group will ensure compliance with the guidelines and conduct on-sight inspections at least once a year at each agency. Kimball asked if that means that ISOO will monitor the agencies, and Theis replied that ISOO will contact the agency head if there is a problem.

Kimball said that the Committee is concerned because there is nothing in the Executive Order addressing other agency equities. Theis replied that the originating
agency has control and responsibility for the declassification of a document. She said that she would be happy to give the Committee a written response on this question. Kimball remarked that they had sent the letter in July. Theis repeated that she will write a response. Kimball said that he has come across the problem with other agency equities in State records; one agency in particular is not cooperating. He wanted to know if the Executive Order provides means to require agencies to cooperate.

Theis said that the purpose of the declassification working group is to raise problems, not policy. If agencies cannot solve problems the issue will go to ISOO to mediate. Kimball said that it is fair to say that CIA equities in State files is a problem the Committee has been fighting for 4 years without progress. He further requested that Theis put the issue on the agenda of the declassification working group.
Theis said that Garfinkel will be more than willing to meet with State and CIA representatives to facilitate an agreement.
Hogan suggested that the Committee put the request in writing to ISOO.

Machak said that the equities issue is a complex problem for other agencies. The only agency that he is comfortable with is NARA. Some people in the Department believe that NARA has tools to help but is not using them, while NARA says the Department’s guidelines are not specific enough. Some agencies have not yet gotten over the shock of the new Executive Order. For agencies that have no relationship with NARA, this has been a difficult period. Some think that the Executive Order does not apply to them, so it has been difficult. State and NARA are pretty much in agreement. He said that he is not a proponent of applying technology to 30 year old documents. He warned that the Committee should not write the Secretary of State. Your targets have to be carefully selected,” he said “You may stop good things at State.” He added that there is a lot of uncertainty about what the provisions of the Executive Order mean.

Kimball remarked that the Department has the law, and for 5 years the Committee has been told that the biggest problem is other-agency equities. He said that he wants to get this on the ISOO agenda. The issue is about process, getting other agencies to participate. He asked if there were any more questions on implementation of the Executive Order. When there were none, he asked Machak if it was safe to say that State was not yet ready to present its implementation plan.

Machak confirmed this. He continued that there is nothing unique about it. He said that they are still at the working level and that they hope to meet the numbers requirement fairly easily (i.e., 15 percent each year for 5 years). He added that FPC is still working to establish its Declassification Center and that the Director General has recognized that FPC needs an infrastructure, that they need to get away from temporary employees. He said that there is a need for site visits. In his opinion there is merit in approaching implementation of the Executive Order much like the Kennedy assassination project, which brought agency resources together. He said that there is no groundswell in other agencies for taking these approaches. Other agencies are looking for precision that will never occur (interpretation of the Executive Order) to manage their limited work force.

Kimball asked if Machak or someone can report to the Committee at the next meeting on the status of implementation or if the Department needs additional Committee support. He said that Machak’s report sounded like “testimony for the liberal approach.”

Machak replied that the Department does not have a liberal approach; his job is to protect national security and individuals. He continued that State does not want to lead the pack. He said that if he had $150,000 he would put it on systematic review rather than on FOIA and get “more bang for the buck.”

Rosenberg commented on the ISOO structure. She said that ISOO anticipates meeting twice a year and having one site visit a year, and that in this Committee’s experience there is a need for more meetings. That is not enough time to catch an agency that is slipping. The Committee has found that regular monitoring is crucial.

Theis replied that the Executive Order requires agency self-inspection programs. ISOO has the option to look at what the agency has done with these self-inspection programs to make sure that they are doing what they are supposed to and that these mechanisms are formal. All of the mechanisms work in tandem to find solutions to the problems.

Kimball asked if there were any other questions on the Executive Order and said that he has notes on the Garfinkel letter and the Committee will talk about them later. He said that Machak and Theis were free to go. He said that the Committee will talk to L, then to Bill concerning problems.

div.head: Status of the Legal Adviser’s Records
div.p: Peter Pfund, Assistant Legal Adviser for Private International Law, attended in place of Bob Dalton. He said that the second volume in the Digest of U.S. Practice in International Law that covers through 1980 has been published and that the third volume will be published soon. However, there is a question whether the Legal Adviser’s Office can continue to produce the series. He said that the International Law Institute, associated with Georgetown University Law, is considering producing a digest of international law in lieu of the Department, but he believes that it would be difficult for an outsider to compile. It would also be difficult to get attorneys in L to devote time to the series. He remarked that the purpose of the Digest needs to be clearly defined, including who is the target audience. Some parts of the Digest would, for example, not be of interest to foreign governments if the first priority purpose of the Digest should be its normative effect on the actions and justifications of the foreign policy of other countries.

Kimball asked Pfund how much of a project it would be to identify who would be the target audience and what should be included in the volumes. Pfund replied that he does not know; L would have to ask the users. The answer will likely be that the users want the Digest. In any event, L does not have the resources to continue the Digest.
Kimball asked Pfund to describe the Digest for the Committee.

Pfund replied that the contents of the Digest have been reduced to what is not readily available in other public sources. He noted that 8 years (when Ronald Reagan was President) have been covered in three volumes, and consequently the coverage is less
complete than before. He added that there is now less quotation from U.S. case law and other published materials.

Kimball leafed through the latest volume of the Digest and noted a section on the Deep Seabed and said that in his opinion that was not an insignificant issue. He asked if that material was readily available elsewhere or if the Digest performs a unique function to pull it all together.
Pfund answered that the Digest pulls things together in an “official” source in a coherent manner.

Picker returned to the question of the target audience, and added that the most recent volumes, including a cumulative index, are all out of print. Copies are grabbed up when they are printed. The demand is higher than the supply.

Pfund brought up the possibility of converting the series to CD-ROM or an on-line service. Picker pointed out the issue of cost. Kimball noted Pfund’s comment that the real problem was getting someone with authority to allocate resources.

Pfund said that the form of the publication should be related to the target audience. Some of the volumes are sold abroad. Picker commented that some are sent to Embassies, and Kimball added that the majority go to government depository libraries and law school libraries. He asked Picker if the Committee should be concerned.

Picker replied that her original concern was whether documents that would have been included in the Digest should be in the Foreign Relations series, and she felt that the Committee needed to consider this. The American Society of International Law has also expressed great concern about discontinuance of the series. Kimball asked if there were any letters on this. Picker replied no, but that L is well aware of ASIL’s concerns. She added that on May 11 she met with Robert Dalton of L and Paul Claussen about getting another organization either to take over the publication or to finance it. The initial response from L was that more than cost was involved. The time devoted by L lawyers to the collection of materials is the real issue. The Committee needs feedback on cost.
Kimball asked if the project is an orphan in the State Department and Pfund replied that it is becoming one. Picker commented that it does have a highly motivated mother (Marian Nash).
Kimball asked if there were any comments on the possible impact of the elimination of the Digest on the Foreign Relations series.

Slany responded that the series does not need to document case law, only the legal framework and explanations for U.S. foreign policy and related decisions. Picker pointed out that the Digest is broader than case law and Pfund agreed that it relates to the many different aspects of U.S. foreign policy.
Hogan recommended that HO look through the volumes, and Pfund suggested that Marian Nash, editor of the Digest, be given a chance to comment.
Kimball said that the Committee needs to find out if this is an issue for concern.
Picker asked Slany to comment on what extent HO should become involved with L and seek access to L files for use in the Foreign Relations volumes.

Slany replied that it is unplowed terrain. HO has not searched L files; they are as obscure to us as the INR files were before we got into them. The files are not routinely retired so that the historians can have access. He said that he did not know if Langbart has had any success with their records.
Langbart replied that he has had some. There is a schedule but it needs work.
Kimball asked that HO study the question: should we be concerned and how?
Claussen said that in some of his research he has used L files extensively, and he added that he knows that members of the international law community use the Digest.

Pfund commented that discontinuing the publication sends a message that resources are not available, once the United States has become the world’s only superpower, to continue to texplain the legal context and justification for U.S. foreign policy, which is not necessarily a good message to send to other countries. Picker pointed out that L is considering discontinuing a series that has been in existence since the beginning of the century.

div.head: Classified Material in Non-Governmental Repositories
div.p: Kimball asked Dalsimer about collections of classified materials in nongovernmental repositories, mentioning as an example the Dulles material at the Seeley Mudd Library at Princeton University. Are the records now automatically part of a systematic review process or are they regularly opened?

Dalsimer replied that he can only discuss the collection he knows of at Princeton. Princeton is an approved repository, so State will either do the review or provide guidelines. He does not know of another collection like this, and worries about non-official repositories and unauthorized release of documents. The Executive Order does not mention these.

Hogan asked what is the issue? Is the material at Seeley Mudd a duplicate set? Kimball said Kissinger claims that his materials at the Library of Congress are only duplicates, but this has not proven to be the case. He added that if the Committee finds other examples, these should be identified so that the State Department can conduct a systematic review.

Langbart explained that Secretary Dulles hired a research assistant and microfilmed material that would illustrate his (Dulles’) impact on foreign policy. Dulles paid for it and owned the film but said that he would abide by the rules for declassification. Kimball repeated that he just wanted to make sure that the material would be reviewed for declassification.
Langbart said that Dulles thought that his papers would eventually all be open. Hogan questioned the quality of the microfilm after such a long period.

Van Camp suggested that the way to identify bodies of records like this is through the Defense Investigative Service, which conducts routine inspections of records
depositories. Dalsimer said that they had checked with DOD about this but were told that they know of no such holdings.

Langbart said that Dulles left a copy of the microfilm at the State Department. Slany said that the Department knows where it is. Dalsimer said that he doesn’t know where it is. Slany said that HDR has it.
Langbart noted another example, the G. Mennen Williams collection at the Michigan Historical Society.
Rosenberg asked if the same procedure was followed for the Humphrey papers at Minnesota. Langbart replied that the Vice President can take whatever he wants.

div.head: Declassification of the Foreign Relations Series
div.p: Kimball asked Slany for an update on declassification of the Foreign Relations series. Slany said that there are the same problems with CIA as reported before. Assistant Secretary/Chief of Staff Donilon and CIA Executive Director Slatkin have worked out and agreed on some principles of declassification. Three volumes have gone to CIA under these guidelines. We will see by February if this system works.

In response to a question from Herring, Herschler said that the China, Laos, and Cyprus volumes were sent to CIA. CIA responses on three other volumes are due: Italy, Africa, and Thailand, and in the case of the Southeast Asia and Africa volumes, the CIA responses are not complete. There are some declassification issues with State as well. Miller interjected that the problem with the Cyprus volume is not Cyprus, but Greece.

Kimball suggested that HO set up a tickler file to revisit the appealed volumes. Hogan asked how often a case could be appealed. Kimball believed that the new E.O. required a 2-year waiting period after the first appeal.

Slany reported that the National Security Agency had filed a FOIA request regarding the Foreign Relations documents and other Department records identified in a New York Times article on Japan. Kimball said that he had heard that.
Hogan went back to the question of re-appeals and asked about the Iran volume. Slany said that the issue will be covered in the intended retrospective volume on covert operations.

Davis remarked that 2 years is too long, it should be 1 year. Hogan suggested that the Committee check the law to see if it really is 2 years. Kimball said that he thought it was tied to costs, etc. and that he is almost positive it is 2 years. Information on this will be included in the briefing material for the next meeting for the Committee to revisit if desired. Slany agreed.
The meeting adjourned at 4:10 p.m.
